notes:
1. Purpose of Ventilation

Ventilation in industrial settings serves two primary purposes:

  • Supply Oxygen: Ensuring the atmosphere contains sufficient oxygen (between 19.5% and 23.5%) for safe breathing.
  • Contaminant Control: Removing or diluting airborne contaminants (gases, vapors, dusts, fumes) to keep their concentration below hazardous levels (such as the PEL or LEL).

2. Calculating Purge Time

Before entering a confined space, the air volume must often be exchanged multiple times to remove contaminants. The time ($t$) required to purge a space of volume ($V$) with a fan of flow rate ($Q$) is:

$$ t = \frac{N \times V}{Q} $$
  • $t$: Time (minutes).
  • $N$: Number of air changes required (typically 5 to 10 for initial purge, depending on regulations and hazard).
  • $V$: Volume of the space (cubic feet or cubic meters).
  • $Q$: Flow rate of the blower (cfm or mÂ³/min).

3. Air Changes per Hour (ACH)

Ventilation rates are often specified in Air Changes per Hour (ACH). One ACH means a volume of air equal to the room volume is supplied and exhausted every hour.

$$ ACH = \frac{Q \times 60}{V} $$

where $Q$ is the flow rate in cfm (cubic feet per minute) and $V$ is the room volume in cubic feet.

solvedExamples.question: A confined space has a volume of 2,000 cubic feet. Safety procedures require 5 air changes before entry. If the ventilation blower has a capacity of 500 cfm, how long will it take to purge the space?
solvedExamples.explanation: Total volume of air to be moved = Number of changes $\times$ Volume = $5 \times 2,000 = 10,000$ cubic feet. Time = Total Volume / Flow Rate = $10,000 \text{ ft}^3 / 500 \text{ cfm} = 20$ minutes.

solvedExamples.question: A laboratory room is 20 ft x 30 ft x 10 ft. The ventilation system supplies 600 cfm of fresh air. What is the ventilation rate in Air Changes per Hour (ACH)?
solvedExamples.explanation: First, calculate the room volume: $V = 20 \times 30 \times 10 = 6,000 \text{ ft}^3$. Next, convert the flow rate to cubic feet per hour: $600 \text{ cfm} \times 60 \text{ min/hr} = 36,000 \text{ ft}^3/\text{hr}$. Finally, divide flow by volume: $ACH = 36,000 / 6,000 = 6$ ACH.
